1.question: Which of the following best describes the primary goal of cluster analysis?

options.A: D) To identify cause-and-effect relationships between variables.
options.B: B) To group similar data objects into clusters based on inherent characteristics.
options.C: C) To predict future trends based on historical data.
options.D: A) To classify data objects into predefined categories.

2.question: Cluster analysis is considered a type of unsupervised learning because:

options.A: A) It requires extensive human supervision to define clusters.
options.B: B) It learns by examples with pre-labeled classes.
options.C: C) It does not rely on predefined classes or labeled data.
options.D: D) It generates new data points from existing ones.

3.question: Which of the following are typical applications of cluster analysis? (Select all that apply)

options.A: A) Disease diagnosis to identify subtypes.
options.B: C) Document clustering for information retrieval.
options.C: B) Predicting stock market prices with 100% accuracy.
options.D: D) Identifying unusual data points as outliers.

4.question: In image processing, clustering can be used for:

options.A: C) Converting images to text.
options.B: B) Grouping similar pixel colors/patterns for compression.
options.C: D) Adding special effects to images.
options.D: A) Enhancing image resolution.

5.question: A good clustering method should ideally produce clusters with:

options.A: D) Random distribution of data points.
options.B: C) High similarity across all clusters.
options.C: B) High intra-class similarity and low inter-class similarity.
options.D: A) Low intra-class similarity and high inter-class similarity.

6.question: The quality of a clustering method is NOT dependent on which of the following?

options.A: A) The similarity measure used by the method.
options.B: B) The implementation of the clustering algorithm.
options.C: C) Its ability to discover hidden patterns.
options.D: D) The subjective preferences of the end-user.

7.question: Which of the following is typically used as a dissimilarity/similarity metric in clustering?

options.A: C) Distance function (e.g., Euclidean).
options.B: D) Variance.
options.C: A) Correlation coefficient.
options.D: B) Regression slope.

8.question: When measuring similarity for clustering, which factors are important considerations? (Select all that apply)

options.A: B) The type of data attributes (numerical, categorical).
options.B: A) The specific distance function chosen.
options.C: C) Applying weights to variables based on importance.
options.D: D) The number of CPU cores available.

9.question: In the context of cluster separation, what is the difference between an "exclusive" and "non-exclusive" cluster?

options.A: D) Exclusive clusters are used for numerical data, non-exclusive for categorical.
options.B: C) Non-exclusive clusters are always hierarchical, exclusive are not.
options.C: B) Exclusive means an object belongs to only one cluster, non-exclusive allows multiple.
options.D: A) Exclusive clusters allow overlap, non-exclusive do not.

10.question: Which of the following are important considerations when performing cluster analysis? (Select all that apply)

options.A: B) The chosen similarity measure (distance-based vs. connectivity-based).
options.B: C) The clustering space (full space vs. subspaces).
options.C: D) The preferred programming language.
options.D: A) Partitioning criteria (single-level vs. hierarchical).

11.question: A major challenge in cluster analysis, especially with real-world data, is:

options.A: C) Manually labeling all data points before clustering.
options.B: A) Ensuring the data is perfectly clean and noise-free.
options.C: B) Discovering clusters with complex or arbitrary shapes.
options.D: D) Limiting the analysis to only numerical attributes.

12.question: Which of the following are key requirements or challenges for effective clustering? (Select all that apply)

options.A: A) Scalability to handle massive datasets.
options.B: C) Interpretability of results.
options.C: B) Ability to deal with only numerical data types.
options.D: D) Handling high dimensionality.

13.question: Which of the following is NOT listed as a major clustering approach category?

options.A: C) Density-based methods.
options.B: B) Regression-based methods.
options.C: D) Hierarchical methods.
options.D: A) Partitioning methods.

14.question: Select all categories of major clustering approaches mentioned in the document.

options.A: A) Grid-based methods.
options.B: B) Model-based methods.
options.C: D) Supervised classification.
options.D: C) Link-based clustering.

15.question: What is a key characteristic of partitioning clustering methods like k-means and k-medoids?

options.A: A) They always produce a tree-like hierarchy of clusters.
options.B: B) They require the number of clusters, 'k', to be specified beforehand.
options.C: D) They are insensitive to noisy data and outliers.
options.D: C) They are exclusively used for categorical data.

16.question: How does k-medoids (PAM) differ from k-means in representing clusters?

options.A: D) K-medoids is suitable for categorical data only, k-means for numerical.
options.B: C) K-medoids is faster and more efficient for large datasets than k-means.
options.C: A) K-medoids uses the mean, while k-means uses the median.
options.D: B) K-medoids uses a real data object as the cluster center, while k-means uses the mean point.

17.question: In the k-means clustering algorithm, what happens in the "Reassign Objects" step?

options.A: A) Objects are randomly assigned to any cluster.
options.B: B) Each object is assigned to the nearest centroid.
options.C: D) Objects are removed if they are outliers.
options.D: C) Centroids are re-calculated based on new assignments.

18.question: What are common weaknesses of the k-means clustering method? (Select all that apply)

options.A: A) It is sensitive to noisy data and outliers.
options.B: C) It requires choosing the number of clusters (k) in advance.
options.C: D) It is typically very slow for large datasets.
options.D: B) It can struggle with complex shape clusters.

19.question: How does hierarchical clustering fundamentally differ from partitioning methods regarding the number of clusters?

options.A: B) Hierarchical methods do not require a predefined 'k' but need a stopping condition.
options.B: C) Partitioning methods produce a dendrogram, while hierarchical methods do not.
options.C: A) Hierarchical methods always produce exactly 'k' clusters.
options.D: D) Hierarchical methods are only used for very small datasets.

20.question: Which of the following statements about AGNES and DIANA are true? (Select all that apply)

options.A: A) AGNES is an agglomerative (bottom-up) method.
options.B: D) AGNES starts with one large cluster and splits it.
options.C: B) DIANA is a divisive (top-down) method.
options.D: C) Both were introduced by Kaufmann and Rousseeuw.

21.question: In hierarchical clustering, the "Single link" method measures the distance between two clusters as:

options.A: C) The largest distance between any two elements, one from each cluster.
options.B: B) The smallest distance between any two elements, one from each cluster.
options.C: A) The average distance between all pairs of elements from both clusters.
options.D: D) The distance between the centroids of the two clusters.

22.question: Which of the following describe valid ways to measure distance between two clusters in hierarchical clustering? (Select all that apply)

options.A: D) Minimum cluster size.
options.B: C) Centroid distance.
options.C: A) Complete link.
options.D: B) Average distance.

23.question: What is a significant advantage of density-based clustering methods?

options.A: C) They can discover clusters of arbitrary shapes.
options.B: D) They are computationally inexpensive for very high-dimensional data.
options.C: B) They require a predefined number of clusters (k).
options.D: A) They always produce spherical clusters.

24.question: In density-based clustering (e.g., DBSCAN), what does "MinPts" refer to?

options.A: A) The minimum distance between two cluster centers.
options.B: B) The minimum number of iterations for the algorithm to converge.
options.C: D) The minimum number of clusters to be formed.
options.D: C) The minimum points required in a neighborhood to form a dense region.

25.question: What is a primary advantage of grid-based clustering methods?

options.A: C) They guarantee the discovery of all possible clusters.
options.B: D) They are exclusively used for categorical data.
options.C: B) They are highly efficient for large datasets due to computations on cells.
options.D: A) They eliminate the need for any input parameters.

26.question: Which of the following is true about CLIQUE clustering? (Select all that apply)

options.A: D) It is an example of a hierarchical clustering method.
options.B: A) It is considered only a density-based method.
options.C: B) It finds clusters in high-dimensional data by identifying dense units in subspaces.
options.D: C) It partitions each dimension into equal length intervals.

27.question: What does a Hopkins Statistic (H) value close to 0 indicate about a dataset?

options.A: B) The data has a strong clustering tendency.
options.B: C) The data contains a high number of outliers.
options.C: D) The optimal number of clusters is zero.
options.D: A) The data is perfectly uniformly distributed.

28.question: If the Hopkins Statistic for a dataset is close to 0.5, what can be inferred about its spatial distribution?

options.A: D) It suggests a need for density-based clustering.
options.B: C) It indicates the presence of a hierarchical structure.
options.C: B) It is uniformly distributed and likely random.
options.D: A) It is highly skewed and shows clear clusters.

29.question: Which method involves plotting the sum of squared distances against the number of clusters to find an "elbow" point?

options.A: C) Elbow method.
options.B: B) Empirical method.
options.C: A) Hopkins Statistic.
options.D: D) Silhouette coefficient.

30.question: What does the cross-validation method for determining 'k' involve? (Select all that apply)

options.A: B) Training clustering models on a subset of data.
options.B: C) Testing the model on a different subset of data.
options.C: A) Splitting the dataset into multiple parts.
options.D: D) Directly calculating 'k' from a predefined formula.

31.question: Which type of clustering quality measurement requires the "ground truth" or real labels for the data?

options.A: C) Unsupervised.
options.B: A) Intrinsic.
options.C: B) Extrinsic.
options.D: D) Density-based.

32.question: The Silhouette coefficient is an example of an intrinsic measure of clustering quality. What does an intrinsic measure typically evaluate? (Select all that apply)

options.A: D) The computational efficiency of the algorithm.
options.B: C) How well the clusters are separated from each other.
options.C: B) How compact the clusters are.
options.D: A) How well the clusters match predefined labels.
